description: Club featuring experimental music and attracting a wide variety of clientele, from punks to suburbanites.

reviews.title: Low frills, no fuss music venue. Long may it continue and be supported by locals.
text: No cover charge, great atmosphere and typically a good variety of musicians on their weekly bill. Only downside is the lack of any food being served, but it's almost entirely about the music in this place, and that's the more important thing.

reviews.title: Toronto music scene
text: Good vibe at CH. we paid to go through the back which was $15 each and saw 3 bands. Real
Mix of stuff but really enjoyed it and very good energy in the room.
Cash only bar so take some $$ with you but an ATM through the front. Craft beers and simple drinks. No wine glasses!
Would definitely go back for another night and area is vibrant with loads of bars/restaurants and takeaways.

reviews.title: Live music!
text: Small venue, long room with a small stage at one end. If you sit on the benches on either side, you have to angle yourself to see the band. It can be uncomfortable after a while, but if the band is good, it’s worth it :)
The night we went it was excellent live music.

reviews.title: Great venue for live music
text: The Cameron House is a staple of mine. I believe it would be classified as a dive bar (in a good way?) or a bit of a hipster joint, but certainly laid back and comfortable with an easy clientele. Some nights the bands are just ok, other times they are fantastic. WIth no cover, pay what you want / can when the band comes around with the jar, it's easy to drop in to see what kind of a night it is. Since the Horseshoe Tavern is also very close, you can do a bit of a music crawl. It does get busy though, so make an effort to arrive at a decent time. Don't expect anything fancy and come with an open mind - you may be very pleasantly surprised!

reviews.title: Great Venue for great music
text: Smooth tunes on a regular basis. Great cozy feel. Not an impressive beer selection but hey drink cocktails.

reviews.title: Great bar, Great band - Hey Stella
text: Absolutely loved this place! Stumbled upon it as we had a couple of days in Toronto before we headed home. The band that came on around 8:30 was stunning! Usually bands of this calibre come with a big ticket price They played country rock and were obviously very experienced musicians...what a treat! The lead singer, Lori Yates - huge voice was super friendly and funny and said they played there every week 8-10 on Tuesdays. We made sure to buy their cd to take home with us! The bar itself is dark and funky with a beautifully painted ceiling. Very down to earth and the bartender was  friendly. No food but there's lots of places around to grab something. You should go!

reviews.title: Excellenet
text: Great music. Toronto has some hidden gems and this is certainly one of those places. Some interesting bands featured.

reviews.title: Simple little bar with great music
text: The Cameron House is a funky little space with small tables and interesting murals. It's a great place to catch local bands and solo musicians. No food is sold here and the bar is cash-only, so come with full stomachs and wallets! There's no cover but 'the jar' is passed around for contributions to the musicians.

reviews.title: Funky little club
text: My husband and I went for the first time and really enjoyed the retro feel of the bar. We were able to catch two excellent bands. The Sinners Choir was a great treat! It is very small with only a few seats but the Architecture and ambiance is lovely. Glad to finally visit.

reviews.title: The Cameron House is an interesting place to hear blues, folk, country and regular music
text: The Cameron House is still decorated in a 1950's style and is a bare bones saloon with some table seating. They serve only drinks, at a very reasonable price, but let people bring in their own food if they want to eat dinner or a snack during the music or in the breaks between music. If you go to the website for ''Cameron House" you can find the listing for the music sessions which occur 7 evenings a week, beginning at 6 pm.  Sometimes when I get inspired by the music we will get up and dance in the space they have available in front of the band. It can be a relaxing and enjoyable evening and can introduce you to musicians you may not have heard before.

reviews.title: Grungy, fun, great music, laid back and an undiscovered tourist gem
text: The Cameron is a grungy, friendly music venue in Toronto - the one review so far cites rudeness, but in the years I've been going there I have NEVER experienced this. There is no pressure to drink, at all, and most of the music in the front room is a "pass the hat" situation. The back room is a 60-seat cabaret venue, and there is usually a small cover charge, depending on the attraction - usually about $10.00. Some of Canada's very best musicians learned their craft ast the Cameron

reviews.title: Great venue - rudest owner I've ever met
text: This venue is lovely and they have some great acts but I won't return. I'm not sure if this guy was the owner or just someone with a huge chip on their shoulder but we were essentially told, unless you're drinking alcohol and a lot of it, don't bother staying because these seats are for our customers who are drinking. I was DD and my friends had drinks on the go, but apparently we weren't ordering them fast enough. We thought he was kidding at first... he wasn't. We left. I'd rather give my money to someone who actually wants customers there.

reviews.title: Love the vibe here!
text: Cameron House is a small bar with kitschy decor which won me over INSTANTLY. It reminded me of my local watering hole – The High Spirits Cafe in Pune. There’s a sign on the wall behind the bar which says ‘this is paradise‘ and there were cowboy boots suspended from the ceiling. We listened to couple of bands playing over drinks before heading back to a friend’s place. It was wonderful.
Note: Cameron House takes cash only, so hit the ATM beforehand.

reviews.title: cameron house
text: For many years the Cameron House has been a centre of the Toronto music and cultural scene. The front room features live music (country and roots) while the back room hosts new music, cd releases, and theatre. Saturday afternoons and evenings are very popular. The drinks are reasonable and the vibe truly excellent. Compares with the Continental Club in Austin, Texas

reviews.title: Great music and service too!
text: Husband and I really enjoyed Emma-Lee's performance last Wed. PM at an entertainment venue we should have discovered previously:  Cameron on Queen West.  It's a quirky old, small bar with a front and back room, both of which have shows at night (not open before 4 pm).  Friendly atmosphere;  loved the Boneshaker on draft at the bar.   Couldn't hear a pin drop from the adoring crowd:  Emma-Lee was fantastic! No cover, but she did ask for donations, and that was a chance to meet her.   After all of the fun, though, silly me, I dropped my wallet and the bartender kept it safe for me:  what excellent service;  so very appreciated as the cost of replacing all of my ID, and the cash lost, it would have been a disaster!   Thank you Cameron, for a great evening, and for saving me from myself:  we'll be sure to come again!

reviews.title: Good music, good cider, good crowd.
text: We walked in because we heard a nice cover of My Girl streaming out the door as people went in and out. The man at the entrance was very friendly and the atmosphere inside was very welcoming and non-threatening. We were told the place is renowned for its craft beer selection, but my friend and I both opted for a cider, which was fantastic and not expensive ( 7 bucks for a pint). The music was steadily good throughout the night as well.

reviews.title: Amazing hole in the wall
text: A grimy hole in the wall with fantastic music. I love dropping in here for a few cheap pints, you never know what music you will hear or what kooky characters you are going to meet. It's fantastic in the dead of winter when its freezing outside and cozy and comfy inside.

reviews.title: where the music is
text: the Cameron House is such an interesting bar.  Clearly it is full of people who appreciate authentic charm and music.  great sound system, friendly staff and truly an entertaining evening.  No cover charge, they pass the hat.

reviews.title: Live Local Mucis
text: We stopped by the Cameron House as it was highly recommended from some locals for live music and good beer.  On the outside you wouldn't know what what building it but it is clearly labeled with the name.  Once inside we were presently surprised the two female bartenders were very nice and helpful.  There was a local artist there who put up his works and had appetizers for everyone.  A Pint was $6 so prices were average.  Nice little place to go and watch live music.  No cover when I was there.

reviews.title: A pleasant discovery
text: A few weeks ago I went with a friend to see an amazing up and coming band there. Being my first time, I was pleasantly surprised by its great sound system and friendly staff. I would recommend it as a music destination to anyone who loves good music and doesn't mind a grungy venue. Best Toronto discovery in quite some time.

reviews.title: Quirky Little Venue
text: Saw a comedy show there, the Emergency Monologues. Highly recommended show if you ever get a chance to see it. A paramedic telling some very animated tales from his experiences. The venue is intimate and fully licensed. Good beer prices for Toronto. Easy to find and to get to via public transit. Nothing to look at from the outside or the inside, you're going for the acts.

reviews.title: Likely the best place in Toronto to see up and coming musicians
text: the nightly house bands from 6 to 8 pm are all fantastic. Over a ten day visit to Toronto I went there 5 different evenings and each one was absolutely great. What an eclectic crowd and venue!
No food and no table service but who cares - go for the music!!!!!!

reviews.title: Little gem
text: Cute place and great music. It's pretty small and not a lot of area to sit. Drinks were pricy and they only take cash so make you you take money out. The machine costs 1.75$

reviews.title: Unpretentious place for good music
text: I live close to this place and I see myself going there everytime I want a good unexpensive night out. Its a bar with a stage in the front and another in the back. Every night of the week they have concerts every two hours and you only need to show up and buy yourself a beer if you are going to the front stage - which is free. The back stage is based on covers (normally around 10-20 bucks).
The atmosphere is really relaxed and attracts all kinds of people of all ages. So you might see some puck people, some high profile people and some homeless people all in one place.
The music is amazing, a lot of folk and rock.
Bring some cash so you can tip the bands.
No food - but there is a bunch of things around
Also: If you are an Orphan Black fan, you might recognize this place!

reviews.title: Walked in the front
text: Wasn't impressed
Three or 4 people not even listening to the music
The place is a dive
Someone was smoking inside perhaps the bartender
The band that was playing were very talented
After a few tunes we left
Not an option to return for us

reviews.title: Love this place
text: Just go there. It's a very friendly bar that has amazing local bands. Caliber of music is high and level of bar coolness is too. Tried to download the three weekday bands we saw. Failed. But go there and enjoy yourself.

reviews.title: Back room vibe
text: These kinds of bars don't exist in small towns.   I really enjoyed the gritty honest vibe of this bar.   The back room costs 5 dollars to enter (not sure why) but the music was good and local.  I generally enjoy all live music, but I understand how some bands might not be for everyone.  Bring cash.  Not cards.  No table service.   Felt safe and yet dark simultaneously.

reviews.title: Great tunes, great community
text: Keep in mind, as a Toronto native, I've spent more then my fair share of time in this venue.

When I get off work, there are very few places I can go to see live music, at 6pm the first band goes on in the front room and It is one of the few places that offers consistent residencies, i.e. every wednesday for a month, you can see the same band, at the same time.
The performers are always top notch, with a lean towards roots, folk, and classic rock'n'roll. Its a real hang out with lots of musicians hanging around.
Also, they have a revolving door of local artists displayed on their walls and the place has an well lived in feel without being too dingy.
With a storied history a youthful energy, the Cameron is worth far more than the price of admission (which in the front room is "pay what you can")

reviews.title: Meh
text: Cool at first, but then it got old quick.  2 rooms to check out.  the back room we paid 5$ cover and it so wasn't worth it.  we came and saw in about an hour's time.  ahh well, good to try something new.

reviews.title: Brilliant spot
text: We stumbled upon this place and absolutely loved it. The music was brilliant and it felt like a real find in the middle of the city. Great fun super music fab decor and staff were friendly .

reviews.title: Kids' Dive Bar
text: Three friends met here on Wednesday night solely to hear a band that has a gig every week here now in "The Back Room" - The Dreamboats.  I was slightly appalled upon entering.  The place looks a little scary at first glance.  It's old and dark and sparsely furnished with what looks like 1960s garage sale offerings.

The ladies room is all the way at the back of the bar, at the very end of The Back Room.  The walls are totally covered in toilet graffiti - some of it pretty offensive - although the toilets and sinks are clean.  The back room is separated from the front via a double layer of heavy velveteen curtains, like something out of a 1960s movie theatre.

The Dreamboats were performing with no cover charge.  The Back Room contains a separate tiny bar, with one red wine choice and one white wine choice.  Fortunately the white was pinot grigio ... it's hard to go wrong with that.  Wine is served in a water glass, but hey, it's only $6.25 (including tax).
Beer is about $5 CAD for a bottle or $7 for a tall can.  There is no food, and there is no table service.  Cameron House doesn't accept debit or credit cards, so bring cash.
The bartender was friendly, the band was awesome, drink prices were reasonable.  By 10:30 the house was packed on a Wednesday night, and there was standing room only.
Having said that, I probably wouldn't go back.  The crowd is too young, and the ambiance is a little too much dive for my taste.

reviews.title: This is Paradise
text: The Cameron House, or just Cameron, is an old, small and very traditional bar cum hotel (longer stay) and has always been a venue for musicians and other performing arts. The best way to describe the interior is one word: eclectic!
Living in the immediate area and finding the various bands and acts of interest, it quickly became a ''once-a-week'' for us, sometimes more often.

It is an old fashioned bar, no table service - you pick up your drinks at the bar and yes, cash only; a recent ''upgrade'' was an added cash-terminal inside. There's no food, but patrons are welcome to bring their own and enjoy simple finger-food with their drinks. I do believe they do sell chips - but lots of small take-out places are nearby on this part of Queen West.
Children - depending on the hour and act, are fine as well; we brought our very young grandchildren many times, and they loved dancing to the music of the ''Cameron Family Singers'' band.
The venue has two rooms, and sometimes different events are in each - which has not been a problem as far as we know. Each room will take up to 60 people, which means standing room only.
So check out their monthly listings and pick a group you'd like to hear, then go and enjoy yourself.
http://www.thecameron.com/listings.html

There is usually no cover, but don't forget to put some money into the pitcher - you'll find it or the band might mention it. If the mood strikes you, pick it up halfway through the final set and collect for the band - it's that kind of place. And be generous!
Below this page asks for ''what sort of visit was this?'' - I could tick every box, but have to pick one.
